newsitem.title: CANADA: British Columbia rules out major stumpage changes.
newsitem.headline: British Columbia rules out major stumpage changes.

text.p: British Columbia ruled out Monday "wholesale" changes to the stumpage system under which it charges forestry companies for the timber they cut.

The province and chief executives from about 20 forest companies have been negotiating for weeks on an accord in which the companies would pledge to increase jobs in exchange for relief from what they contend are excessive costs and regulations.
But Premier Glen Clark, in a text of comments released on Monday, appeared to dismiss any major concessions.

"A change in our stumpage system, as advocated by some, is simply not on. It wouldn't be sustainable in the face of softwood lumber (trade) rulings and would provoke a tough response from the Americans," he said.
"We can look at some adjustments where economic realities require it but not wholesale change," he said.

Stumpage rates have been raised sharply in recent years. The move was partly in response to demands from the United States, which claimed the British Columbia industry was in effect received government subsidies in the form of low stumpage rates.
